title: Grateful Dead Live at Colt Park on 1976-08-02
lineage: Transfer: MAC > Nakamichi CR-5A > Edirol FA-66 > Wavelab 2448 > CD-Wave (24bit output) > TLH > FLAC 2448 tagged. Transferred by Andrew F. 03/2021

reviews.review_text:
hoots and hollers Well,  sounds like a FUN show and ironically, not a bad recording considering the circumstances and gear.   I wonder the position of the mics, sounds hip level to me?  However,  you can still tell that the PA sound was fairly crisp with articulated cymbals, and some booming bass. What amazes me the most about older audience source tapes, is you can really hear the GD's PA was loud and clear most of the time.  Many people believe the GD always had the best sounding PA especially during the 70s.  Again, they understood how to get  a Hi Fi sound by using custom speakers from John Meyer; to me, that's probably the main reason.  PA speakers just were not good back then ... simple horns, and woofers that were not efficient at all ... 

be forewarned .... there are lots of hoots and hollers on this tape, but it's kinda funny hearing these folks... they gotta be really , really ... well, you know ....

Deal? Deal! I didn't attend this show. I didn't have to, because due to some strange atmospheric phenomenon, I could hear the music quite plainly from our backyard in a suburb 6 miles away. I was only 15, but that experience lit a fire under me that still hurts like hell in a good way. It's just as well that I didn't go considering the brouhaha that finished the evening. In that bicentennial year, there was an amazing series of shows at Colt-- Stills-Young/Poco, Starship/Fleetwood Mac, Geils/Tull, James Taylor, Kiss, Frampton, Yes; an all-star summer. I'm giving 4 stars bc there's a lot of crowd noise. Samson and Delilah is awesome, you can tell that them guys are having a LOT of fun.
